title: Monday, 24th April, 2017

BE11:07am

A positive particularly for the strategists, who could use all their pre-written bumf and send it out on Sunday evening. There's tonnes of it.

11:07 am
PM11:08am

It's the Trump effect of course -- as in this hope I had - that the French nation would not like to look like idiot brits and Americans

PM11:08am

Boncoeur -- this is true

PM11:09am

I guess we should share some of the strategists

11:09 am
BE11:09am

JP Morgan.

BE11:10am

The projections and the preliminary results of the French Presidential election confirmed our baseline scenario
with Macron and Le Pen reaching the second round. These results are strongly in line with the latest polls into the election and confirm after the Dutch parliamentary election in March the recent reliability of polls. The concern about a bias underestimating the support of non-mainstream party did not materialize in France.

Going into the second round we believe the strong lead for Macron (around 20%) provides a buffer against a surprise and we reiterate our baseline scenario of a Macron Presidency. The fact that the initial results for the first round are consistent with the polls should improve confidence in the second round estimates: the gap between Macron and Le Pen is well wider than any statistic margin of error. Some might worry about a hung Parliament after the June vote but we believe the markets will focus on having avoided tail risks. Moreover the endorsement of Hamon and Fillon to Macron for the second round should also reduce the degree of uncertainty on the final vote on 7 May.

BE11:10am

What are the market implications?

As discussed in Dernière note avant le premier tour : What to expect in rates & FX after the first round, we expect a sell off of as much as 10bp in 10Y Bunds and 2Y Schatz, and a compression in intra-EMU spreads, with 10Y France-Germany around 50bp and 10Y Italy-Germany around 180bp. We expect 4-6bp narrowing in Bund and Schatz swap spreads at the opening, lower Bund and Schatz implied vol towards 4 and 3bp/day, respectively, with narrower FRA/OIS and EUR/USD cross currency basis as some of the hedges get unwound.

In Euro cash bonds, we entered the first round with a risk-on portfolio of short 30Y Germany, 2s/5s & 7s/15s German steepeners, OW basket of 10Y France-Spain-Italy vs. Germany, OW 5Y Cyprus vs. Germany and OW 20Y Greece, with cheap hedges such as UW 6Y Belgium vs. Finland, UW 10Y+ Austria vs. Germany, 3s/10s credit curve flatteners in France, Spain and Portugal, OW low-coupon vs. high coupon bonds in Italy & Spain, long protection in 5Y USD CDS 2003 contract & UW CCTeus vs. BTPs. We expect to keep the portfolio unchanged but we will revisit our views after the market opens tomorrow morning.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Okay, that was perhaps overtechnical.

BE11:11am

Anything more readable?

PM11:11am

Sure

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Here's some UBS

PM11:11am

First order market reaction to first round resultsGiven that opinion polls were roughly consistent with the reported preliminary result, the market is likely to project higher odds of a benign scenario for risky assets in the second round. As our macro strategy colleagues have extensively discussed (see e.g. Lesson learned: French elections aftermath), the elimination of French risk may reduce the political risk premium (although not eliminate it) across Euro-area assets. If Macron were to ultimately win for instance, they project tighter peripheral spreads by up to 40-50bps, a rise in the EUR/$ by c. 2% on the way to their year-end 1.13 forecast and higher Bund yields (c. 10bps) and Treasuries. Equally, European equities and rate sensitive equity sectors (e.g. financials) could benefit

PM11:11am

Opposing programmes of the two candidatesSee Figure 2 for an overview of the programmes of both candidates. Emmanuel Macron's plans are in favour of more European integration, he plans to observe the European fiscal rules and has an explicit pro-growth agenda (though more moderate than François Fillon). By contrast, Marine Le Pen proposes to hold a referendum on EU membership if elected. Opinion polls suggest that economic issues dominate voters' concerns (Figure 3).

11:11 am
PM11:12am

Three scenarios for round 2As we noted before, we see three scenarios for the elections. First, a 'reform optimism scenario' in the case of a Macron win (which combined with France's relatively stronger growth of the working-age population could improve longer-run growth outcomes, see France: Looking (way) beyond the elections). Second, a 'Eurozone break-up fear' scenario following a Le Pen victory. Severe legal hurdles for implementing a referendum to leave the EU (see details in our note here) and broad support among the French for maintaining euro membership may limit the consequences of this scenario. Third, a status quo scenario whereby the president and prime minister operate under a cohabitation, limiting the ability of any president to push through his or her agenda in full. This shows the importance of the parliamentary elections in June.

BE11:14am

Just before moving on from strategy ......

BE11:14am

Just chanced upon Andrew Lapthorne's latest while looking for French stuff.

BE11:14am

11:14 am
BE11:14am

It's scary!

BE11:14am

Global equity markets have gone nowhere for the last couple of months. Politics is highlighted as the main barrier to further progress with Trump yet to deliver on many of his election promises and European investors concerned about the outcome of the French election. With the latter seemingly out of the way, markets are responding positively, much in the same way the Russell 2000 bounced post Trump. We have no political expertise but nonetheless recognise the palpable relief but we also understand the real problem for equities worldwide is one of high valuations, high expectations, yet still lacklustre growth and ever worrying and mounting levels of leverage. As with Trump any euphoria surrounding Macron will rapidly turn to a focus on delivery.

Regular readers will know will have been flagging the US debt issue for a long-time (for example Are central bank policies going to destroy corporate America?), but for many it is the dog that refuses to bark. But with the IMF in its latest Global Financial Stability report joining the ever increasing list of organisations to be very worried about US corporate leverage (see the US Office of Financial Stability reports for others), the US corporate debt bubble is likely to regain centre stage.

The problem the US now faces is it has to normalise interest rates, but with the smallest 50% of companies already spending 30% of profits (and at peak EBIT) on interest rate costs, any move upwards is likely to push up interest costs to dangerous levels. If EBIT was also to fall as a consequence, a large number of US companies could quickly find themselves in trouble. But if you fail to normalise rates, what is going to stop US corporates taking on even more debt?

BE11:18am

In terms of the banks -- since you mentioned them -- I think Investec is no longer selling HSBC

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 635.40, up 11.4 (+1.83%), High: 638.20, Low: 632.50, Volume: 12.93m
11:19 am
PM11:19am

It's a reluctant upgrade to hold from Trader Gordon

BE11:19am

Yep.

BE11:19am

We freely acknowledge that the timing of this upgrade to Hold (from Sell) may appear a little odd. The “technical support” provided by HSBC’s latest $1bn share buyback has recently expired, and £$ has now started to rally – a headwind for the HSBC’s £ share price. However, a 2017 year-end 1.35 £$ exchange rate is (for us) an unchanged expectation, and after a 13% 2-month share price correction, our price objective has been met, and we judge that the risk:reward is now more balanced (with a small positive skew). HOLD.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The size of the $1bn H1 2017 share buyback announced alongside HSBC’s awful Q4 2016 results was a source of disappointment to many. Moreover, the fact that it has now been executed “expensively” – 122.6m shares purchased at a VWAP of 658.11p – arguably renders the exercise less accretive than perhaps was hoped. Be that as it may, we think that HSBC will exceed its own implicit guidance and announce a further $2bn share buyback in August.

We observe that HSBC has worked hard to “inform” sellside forecasts. As at 16 February 2017, company-compiled consensus for underlying 2017 group revenues stood at $51.6bn. This has now fallen to $49.4bn, with downgrades suitably encouraged by both the $1.1bn revenue miss in Q4 2016 and the explicit highlighting of $3.4bn specific YoY revenue headwinds in 2017 (FX, TLAC, UK interest rates and CML run-off).

BE11:19am

In truth, most of these headwinds were (or should have been) known. Moreover we continue to assume that £/$ will rebound to 1.35 by end 2017. If correct that should (in H2 2017e) translate into a revenue/EPS tailwind. We anticipate a reasonably robust Q1 2017e performance with EPS of 14.4c (Q1 2016: 19.7c). No Q1 consensus is yet available. For full-year 2017e, our 48.6c forecast is now c.1% above latest company-compiled consensus.

Trading on 1.2x 2016 tNAV, our 620p TP is maintained. As such, with minimal residual implied further downside for the share price, and given a 6.4% 2016 dividend yield which we regard as sustainable, we upgrade to Hold (from Sell). However, we continue to prefer Aldermore (Buy), Virgin Money (Buy), Lloyds (Buy), Barclays (Buy) and OneSavings (Buy).

BE11:20am

Actually, he's been seller for a little while. At least by his standards.

11:20 am
PM11:21am

We should also share Gordon on Lloyds

PM11:21am

Where he's crowing a little...

PM11:21am

Sellside humiliation is not yet complete…

11:21 am
PM11:21am

We expect Lloyds’ Q1 2017 IMS to “beat” on NIM, costs, impairments and capital. In aggregate we forecast a 6% u/l PBT “beat” (£2,002m vs £1,897m). However, in particular, we urge investors to focus on the evolving consensus for impairments. Lloyds (and Virgin Money (Buy)) have faced a recent barrage of sellside negativity around perceived deteriorating impairment trends within personal unsecured, yet consensus estimates suggest that analysts do not believe their own rhetoric. We think further upgrades beckon.

PM11:21am

We could simply observe that with UK unemployment at a 40-year low and UK interest rates at 300-year lows, “Brexit Britain” is booming. Indeed, irrespective of one’s view on the eventual level of Brexit benefit, even with an element of transitory imported inflation and/or moderate compression in household disposable incomes we do not believe that the scale and pace of impairment deterioration contemplated by consensus is credible.

We certainly believe that those looking for near-term disappointment are, once again, set to be frustrated, yet some hold out the recent Bank of England Q1 2017 Credit Conditions Survey as offering confirmation for their bearishness. Really? ”Default rates on credit card lending to households were reported to have fallen in Q1, as were losses given default. The latter were expected to fall again in Q2.” So we take the opposite view. Buy and 74p TP reaffirmed.

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 65.85, up 1.48 (+2.30%), High: 66.09, Low: 65.22, Volume: 141.71m

BE11:23am

So ......................

BE11:23am

11:23 am

BE11:23am

On the back of the Sunday Times story on price caps.

BE11:24am

Which is pre-electioneering that's totally different, needless to say, from the price caps proposed by Milliband last time round.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

The main difference is that we know even less about how it all might work.

BE11:25am

Headline is that the average household under a standard variable tariff could see a £100 reduction.

BE11:25am

How? Um .................... dunno.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

No one knows

BE11:26am

What we can say is that apparently, 70% of retail customers are on SVT rather than a "discount" tariff.

BE11:27am

Though as we've seen, discount tariffs aren't particularly discount when the SVT moves against the rate at which you've fixed.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

As in, Telecom Plus. But that's retracing old ground.

BE11:28am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:28am

Whether this ends up being an election commitment or not, the Work and Pensions Secretary (Damian Green) said on ITV Sunday that "there will be a lot about energy policy in the manifesto and obviously there will be more detail". We will have to await the manifesto for this detail.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

This has been one of a number of suggestions with regard energy tariffs: As we showed in our recent report (UK Energy Supply: What changes and when?), it has been clear that some potential changes to tariffs were possible, with focus on extending price caps to fuel poor customers, or limiting the gap between a supplier's discount tariff and SVT. However a wider ranging price cap across all SVT customers could have a greater impact on profitability for energy suppliers. We showed some sensitivities to earnings in that note.

BE11:28am

How would a price cap work? This is unclear. Mr. Green on Sunday morning suggested Ofgem would set the limits. But is there a flat cap? A limit per company? What duration? The Times article suggested it would be similar to the PPM cap and be region by region (this is in place until 2020), but there are no concrete details. But a point to note - as we showed in our recent report (and here again in exhibit 1), the gap between the SVT amounts for an average user at the big 6 energy firms is greater than £100 - we currently see Centrica with a SVT of c.GBP1040, and Npower (Innogy) at the upper end with c.GBP1200 per annum (it will be different region to region). GBP100 off every SVT bill would be negative for all suppliers, but if there is a flat cap, perhaps it wouldn't impact all suppliers evenly?

BE11:29am

What could the impact be? Without detail, this is purely guesswork. It could be material to EPS. But how much would depend on the level of cap; whether it would be company specific; when it could come in to force (remember it took 13 months to deliver the PPM cap on tariffs, so that would imply next summer at the earliest); the duration (the PPM cap runs until 2020 - could this SVT cap be in place for only a year or two?); and the amount of mitigation companies could take (e.g. cost saving initiatives ahead of any implementation). The final impact might not actually be too meaningful. But of course there is no clarity for now.

11:00 am
PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:29am

What about smaller suppliers? Presumably this cap would be for all suppliers, not just the big 6. Not only could it put profitability under pressure for large suppliers, but potentially small suppliers as well. If a price cap pushes some suppliers out of business, especially small suppliers, could this end up forcing customers back to the big 6? Surely this is the exact opposite of what government and consumer groups are looking for, and would reduce, rather than increase competition.

BE11:29am

...... though it's a lot of finger in the air forecasting.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Still going.

BE11:30am

How will energy suppliers react? It depends on the final outcome of course. They could look to take costs out of the business to try to offset some potential earnings impact (more savings would be possible the longer it takes to implement any potential change in tariff). But if it materially reduces supply profitability (or in fact causes losses), will all of them want to remain in the market? For the likes of Innogy, EON, Iberdrola, and EDF, who still have a substantial number of customers, but UK supply is a smaller part of their overall integrated utility business, will they want to remain running a loss making UK supply business? Perhaps better to exit the market and deploy capital elsewhere?

BE11:30am

No quick answers...: There is lots of uncertainty. We need to first see what the Conservative party puts in its manifesto as a pledge. We then need to see the outcome of the UK general election - and so we will be looking at proposals from other parties in the coming weeks as well. But remember, whatever goes in to manifestos will be proposals, and may not be the final outcome.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

No quick answers -- but the stock damage is there

11:31 am
BE11:31am

NP. My PC's on go-slow mode.

BE11:32am

They installed McAfee Something on it, which can't be disabled in any way and seems to choose moments of high activity -- such as 11.30am on a weekday -- to start a deep scan.

BE11:32am

...lobbying and debate to come: We see little likelihood of an earnings impact in 2017 for now, but sentiment will remain weak until (and maybe beyond) the time that there is more clarity. We therefore expect to see further underperformance, in particular for Centrica and SSE. But this debate will go on for some time, and could have repercussions beyond just energy markets. At a time when government and the regulator are looking to increase customer involvement, they could well end up implementing measures to quell it. But beyond this, with Brexit negotiations to come, it could create greater uncertainty around foreign investment in to the UK.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Have RBC as well, for some more specul-analysis.

BE11:33am

Most press articles have suggested that a cap would be administered by Ofgem and would see a reduction of ~£100 to the average standard variable dual fuel bill. The advantage of Ofgem setting a cap, according to the Conservatives, is that it will be able to move with market conditions rather than being set at an arbitrary level.

Without questioning the wisdom of introducing price caps we show below that the scale of intervention that reduces average SVT bills by ~£100 is very meaningful. Despite recent weakness in the share prices of the likes of CNA and SSE, we expect the additional newsflow over the weekend will cause further weakness today.

BE11:33am

Any such intervention will take time to implement, and will need a consultation period post the publication of final proposals. Any intervention is also difficult to fully quantify until we understand the full details. However, if we look at the impact of reducing average SVT bills across the Big Six by £100 the impact is as follows.

· EPS in CNA and SSE could fall 20-30% - based on the relative exposures to the SVT market we could see (without offsetting factors) EPS falls in 2018E over 30% for CNA, over 20% for SSE and ~10% for each of E.ON, innogy and EDF. Iberdrola (Scottish Power) looks to be least exposed with a potential EPS hit of ~5%.
· Dividends therefore at risk - With changes to earnings of this magnitude, the sustainability of dividend levels at both CNA and SSE would then be called into question. With payout ratios at both jumping to ~100%.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Our analysis is likely to be a worst case and remains relatively basic at this stage. What this analysis doesn’t truly reflect is the differing competitive positions of the major suppliers. We imagine Ofgem would take the approach of trying to establish a ‘fair’ SVT tariff based on a benchmarking exercise on the cost bases of the suppliers and it will not be as simple as reducing the current tariffs by £100. Nevertheless, intervention now seems a certainty and the impact will be meaningful and we expect extended weakness in the share prices of CNA and SSE.

PM11:41am

JAB's ownership history is interesting

11:41 am
PM11:41am

From wikipedia..

PM11:41am

Owned by Germany’s Reimann family,[19] 95% of JAB Holding belongs to four of the late Albert Reimann Jr.'s nine adopted children. They are "descendants" of chemist Ludwig Reimann, who, in 1828, joined with Johann Adam Benckiser (founder of the namesake chemical company). Reimann married one of Benckiser's daughters and ended up owning the business. Great-grandson Albert Reimann Jr. took over after his father died in 1952, and added consumer goods.
Initially each of the nine children had inherited 11.1% ownership in JAB upon Albert's death in 1984. In the following years, five of the heirs sold their stakes to the other four: Matthias Reimann-Andersen, Renate Reimann-Haas, Stefan Reimann-Andersen and Wolfgang Reimann. As of January 2015, each of the four owns about $3.8 billion in JAB shares.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Quick line from Bernstein on the strategy plan, though not the higher offer because that's only just broken.

BE11:51am

(1) Akzo's plan, if taken at face value, would lead to a valuation in the high €90s/sh, above PPG's offer of €90 and our ~€78/sh for Akzo standalone (inc. SC separation) (Exhibits 1 &2).

(2) Although we hold Mr Büchner in high regard, we think the 2020 targets are too aggressive (Exhibits 5 & 6) as they are heavily dependent on strong sales growth, while simultaneously very tightly managing costs (Exhibit 5); our expectations are more conservative (Exhibit 6).

(3) The SC separation is the right step, but it also carries risk as the valuation is highly uncertain (we model €8bn EV) (Exhibits 7 & 8), as is the perceived conglomerate discount they hope to unlock (we assume 10% but we have heard a wide range from investors).

(4) Returning cash to shareholders is also a positive, but also with risk. However, the proceeds from SC could disappoint, not only on the overall EV, but also once potential tax liabilities (which were not addressed) and contributions to the pension deficit are factored in.

(5) AkzoNobel repeatedly referred to the risks associated with PPG's offer; however, we see just as much risk, if not more, associated with Akzo's new plan. We still think they owe it to their shareholders to negotiate with PPG and compare options side by side.

BE11:52am

BE11:56am

BE11:57am

Jefferies' Europe and Paper & Packaging Wrap just happens to be on my screen right now, so here it comes.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Testliner and kraftliner grind higher: Since our last Packaging Wrap on March 27, Benchmark European testliner and kraftliner prices continued to grind higher, posting 2% and 3% gains respectively. Since Jan 2017 trough: testliner has risen €56/t (13%) with kraftliner up €44/t (8%). Success in initial round of 2017 price hikes combined with strong market demand and rising raw material costs (OCC), prompted leading European containerboard producers (SKG, SMDS, MNDI) to announce a second round of hikes: targeting €40/t for testliner from April 3 and €50/t for kraftliner from May onwards.

BE11:57am

OCC easing as China exports decline: China has started a “National Sword” program aimed at improving quality of imported materials leading to closer inspections and rejections of recovered paper & boxes. Benchmark imported Chinese OCC prices have fallen 15%-20% over past month (Source: RISI). With up to 20% of European OCC exported to Asia, this decline has seen European OCC prices ease 3% in past fortnight. Obviously; this may impact on-going negotiations on second round of European containerboard hikes [€40/t for testliner, €50/t for kraftliner]. We look to Smurfit Kappa May 5 Q1 results for an update on current price negotiations.

BE11:58am

So .... FX plus testliner and kraftliner price hikes heading into numbers. That'll do for a reason, right?
